content.text: Once upon a time, when wishes still came true, there lived a king whose daughters were all beautiful, but the youngest was so lovely that even the sun, which has seen so much, marveled each time it shone upon her face.
Now, near the king’s castle lay a great dark forest, and in the forest, beneath an old linden tree, was a deep well.
When the day was very hot, the king’s youngest daughter would go into the forest and sit by the edge of the cool well.
To pass the time, she would take her golden ball, toss it high into the air, and catch it again.
This was her favorite plaything.
One day, however, as she reached out her hands to catch the ball, it slipped through her fingers, bounced once on the ground, and rolled straight into the well.
The princess watched in dismay as it sank out of sight.
The well was so deep that she could not see the bottom, and she began to weep bitterly.
While she was crying, she heard a voice say, "Why are you weeping, princess?
Your tears could melt even the hardest stone."  She looked up and saw a frog stretching his thick, ugly head out of the water.
"Oh, it’s you, old water-splasher," she said.
"I am crying because my golden ball has fallen into the well."  "I can fetch it for you," said the frog, "but what will you give me if I bring it back?"  "Whatever you wish, dear frog," she replied.
"My clothes, my jewels, even my golden crown."  The frog shook his head.
"I do not care for your clothes, your jewels, or your golden crown.

But if you will love me and let me be your companion, sit beside you at the table, eat from your little golden plate, drink from your little golden cup, and sleep in your little bed—if you promise me this, I will dive down and bring back your golden ball."  The princess thought to herself, "What nonsense the silly frog is talking!
He sits in the water with his own kind and croaks.
How could he ever be a companion to a human?" But aloud, she said, "Yes, yes, I promise.
Just bring me my ball!"  The frog dove beneath the water, and after a little while, he came swimming back up with the golden ball in his mouth.
He tossed it onto the grass, and the princess was overjoyed.
She snatched it up and ran away as fast as she could, without even looking back. "Wait!
Wait!" called the frog. "Take me with you!
I cannot run as fast as you!" But the princess paid no heed.
She hurried home and soon forgot all about the poor frog, who had to hop back into his well.
The next day, as the princess sat at the table with the king and all the court, eating from her little golden plate, there came a sound at the palace door: plip, plop, plip, plop.
Then a voice cried out:  "Youngest daughter of the king, Open wide the door for me!
Mind the words that you did say By the well so cool and deep.
Youngest daughter of the king, Open wide the door for me!"  The princess ran to the door and opened it, and there stood the frog.
She slammed the door shut in a fright and hurried back to the table.
The king noticed how pale she had become. "My child," he said, "what are you afraid of?
Is there a giant at the door who wants to carry you away?"  "Oh, no," she answered.
"It is no giant, but a nasty frog."  "And what does the frog want with you?" asked the king.
She told him everything—how her golden ball had fallen into the well, how the frog had fetched it for her, and how she had promised to let him be her companion.
But she had not thought he would ever leave the well.
Just then, there came another knock at the door, and the same voice cried:  "Youngest daughter of the king, Open wide the door for me!
Mind the words that you did say By the well so cool and deep.
Youngest daughter of the king, Open wide the door for me!"  The king said, "What you have promised, you must keep.
Go and let him in."  The princess went and opened the door, and the frog hopped in after her.
He followed her to her chair, and when she sat down, he cried, "Lift me up beside you!"  She hesitated, but the king gave her a stern look, so she picked up the frog and set him on the chair.
Then he said, "Now push your little golden plate closer, so that we may eat together."  She did as he asked, though she did so with great reluctance.
The frog ate heartily, but the princess could scarcely swallow a bite.
At last, the frog said, "I have eaten my fill and am tired.
Carry me to your little room and make ready your little silken bed, so that we may sleep."  The princess began to cry, for she was afraid of the cold frog and did not want him to touch her.
But the king said again, "What you have promised, you must keep."  So she picked up the frog with two fingers, carried him upstairs, and set him in a corner.
But as she lay down in her bed, he crept over and said, "I am tired, and I want to sleep as well as you.
Lift me up or I will tell your father!"  At this, the princess grew very angry.
She picked him up and threw him with all her might against the wall.
"Now you will have your rest, you nasty frog!" she cried.
But when he fell to the ground, he was no longer a frog.
There stood before her a handsome prince with kind eyes and a gentle smile.
He told her that he had been enchanted by a wicked witch, and that only the kindness of a princess who would let him eat from her plate and sleep in her bed could break the spell.
The next morning, a splendid carriage drawn by eight white horses, with feathered plumes and golden harnesses, arrived at the palace.
The prince’s faithful servant, Heinrich, had come to take his master home.
Heinrich had been so grieved when his master was turned into a frog that he had ordered three iron bands to be placed around his heart to keep it from breaking.
But now that the prince was free, the bands burst with joy.
The prince asked the princess if she would go with him to his kingdom, and she, seeing how noble and kind he was, agreed.
So they climbed into the carriage, and Heinrich drove them away.
As they rode, the prince heard a cracking sound behind them.
"Heinrich," he said, "the carriage is breaking!"  "No, my lord," replied Heinrich.
"It is not the carriage, but the bands around my heart.
When you were a frog, I was so sad that I had them put there to keep my heart from bursting.
Now that you are free, they have broken with joy."  And so the prince and the princess were married, and they lived happily for many, many years.
